"SECTION 1. FINDINGS."

Summarized: Section 1 presents the findings. Congress finds that Jackie Roosevelt Robinson, born on January 31, 1919, in Cairo, Georgia, was a standout athlete at the University of California Los Angeles, excelling in multiple sports. In 1947, he made history by becoming the first black player in Major League Baseball when he signed with the Brooklyn Dodgers. This event is considered a significant moment in professional sports history. Jackie Robinson, known for his remarkable skills, became the first black player in Major League Baseball when signed by the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947. He won the National League's Rookie of the Year Award in his first season and was voted the National League's Most Valuable Player in 1949. In 1962, Jackie Robinson was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame for his significant contributions to professional sports in America. His achievements on the field led to broader impacts on civil and human rights in the country. Jackie Robinson's election to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962 marked his achievements in athletics and their profound influence on civil and human rights in America, predating key events in desegregation and civil rights movements. Jackie Robinson was the first black player in Major League Baseball, signing before the desegregation of the military, civil rights marches, and the Brown v. Board of Education ruling. He quickly gained public admiration for his fortitude, integrity, and athletic ability, surpassing notable figures like President Harry Truman and General Dwight Eisenhower by the end of 1947. Jackie Robinson ranked second only to Bing Crosby in a national poll for the most popular person in America. Robinson's influence extended to political leaders and he worked with various organizations to improve the lives of Americans. His life and principles are honored through the Jackie Robinson Foundation. Jackie Robinson, one of the greatest political leaders in America, worked tirelessly with religious and civic organizations to better the lives of all Americans. His legacy and personal achievements as an athlete, business leader, and citizen have had a lasting and positive influence on civil rights in the United States. The Jackie Robinson Foundation keeps his memory alive by providing leadership and educational opportunities to children of low-income families. The President is authorized to present a gold medal to Jackie Robinson's family in recognition of his contributions to the nation. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike the medal with suitable emblems and inscriptions. Duplicate medals are also authorized. The Secretary is authorized to strike and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal at a price covering costs. The medals are considered national medals, and appropriations are authorized. The medals struck under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code. An amount not to exceed $30,000 is authorized to pay for the cost of the medal, with proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. Congress believes there should be a national day to honor Jackie Robinson's achievements, with the President issuing a proclamation for its observance. The Senate passed S. 300 on October 17, 2003, to award a congressional gold medal to Jackie Robinson posthumously for his contributions to the nation. Congress also expressed the need for a national day in recognition of Jackie Robinson.
